ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

Natalie Allan
Natalie Allan
Natalie Allen
Natalie

Natalie Alan
Natalie allan
Natalie Allan
Natalie Allen

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: There were several out of class assignments during the semester. My one wish is that they would have been announced at least two weeks prior to their due date. I would have liked to spend more time on them and do a much better job on them. Each homework assignment was announced just one week prior to their due date. This was sufficient but it made for a sleepless week.
Question 3: The HGR report would have been more useful if it was focused around am applied problem and/or had clearer description.Question 7: The TA was very helpful and kept the course on schedule.
Important to note that I audited this class only.

(1) It would be helpful to have some more basic readings to provide a foundation for people who are new to hydrology.(2) I think we should have started with some basics before jumping right in. Not just for review for those new to the topic, but just to provide better structure to the course.(3) I found the assignments to be very frustrating--they required a lot of busywork but did not result in a better understanding of the concepts. They could be much better designed.(7) Natalie did a good job organizing field trips and such, but could have gone further to help us understand the material and prepare for assignments/exams.

General: Jim is a very experienced practitioner with years of varied water resource engineering and restoration work under his belt. He knows a LOT. Unfortunately, the pacing of his classroom lectures is often too fast as he moves from detail to detail and too slow as he transitions from general concept to general concept. He also has a hard time, given the enormous wealth of information he has to share, with indicating which parts are more and less important to pay attention to. The result is sort of a long mishmash of information which, when you review your notes after lecture, you're not sure which bits of information to focus on and draw connections from, which to try to memorize, and which are just interesting trivia.Q1: Cool that he used agency manuals and primary articles, but he also has a handbook that he has written with materials for the whole course. I did not purchase this handbook and only read two chapters specifically assigned for a paper; those chapters suffered from the same organizational problems as Jim's lectures do.Q9: FIELD TRIPS were by far the best part of this course. I only wish we could have done more. Jim's knowledge and teaching style comes alive in the field, you can see from how he works and thinks about rivers which parts of his material are important to know.
James MacBroom has a great deal of enthusiasm and loves talking about rivers. This comes across during his teaching. He is extremely knowledgeable AND experienced.
The group final project is very very valuable. I think the applied nature of the project and the fact that it is completed for a client is the best part of the class.

Jim is an amazing professor who has so much knowledge on the topic as well as many other fields. I was impressed by how much he knew as well as how willing and eager he was to share this information with the class. He was one of the nicest and most caring professors I've ever had and really made the class pleasant as well as informative.
Great practitioner taking that approach to teaching means you learn a lot of interesting parts related to application.

It is a pleasure to learn about this subject matter from an expert in the field. Professor MacBroom adds tremendous insight into difficult materials, and is especially engaging in the field. The field trips were fantastic.
Field trips with Jim.
Field trips and real-life projects really helped teach through actually application and use. Never felt like busy work.
The field trips were great and Jim was extremely willing to help us with our course projects by taking us out in the field. These trips were the best part of the course.
Field trips!
The field trips were fantastic and by far the best part of the course. They offered an extremely useful way in which to understand concepts presented in class.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I learned a great deal during the field trips. I wish we had more field trips.

I think it would be good if the course had a clear syllabus, listing all assignments and their due dates.Some of the lectures seemed partially redundant. I think the course could be improved by better organizing the lecture subjects.The all day field trip for the final project was very useful. However, I think the other field trips either should be made longer (although this is capped by the class time, obviously) or made more applied (taking measurements, etc. rather than just an outside lecture.
Jim's 3 hour lectures, which are too fast-paced for that long a session, in that format, that early in the morning.
Some of the homework assignments, compared to the field trips and bigger projects, did feel like busy work. The 10 page paper on regime equations seemed a little bit excessive.
The lectures were all interesting but three hours of lecture is a long time. I think the class could benefit from more discussion.

I wish it could be done in twice weekly meetings rather than three-hour blocks...I think that might help with the problem of organizing information efficiently. Or, incorporating a short field trip every week or every other week for the second half of class.Also, instructions regarding the homework assignments (not the final paper) were very unclear, often provided at the last minute without any advance warning of due dates (like in high school), and had wildly unrealistic word count requirements. I could have written a satisfactory paper comparing hydraulic geometry with geomorphic equations in two pages rather than the assigned seven, for instance.

While the quantitative problem set was quite useful for strengthening concepts learned in class, I found the qualitative assignments to not be as worthwhile as they could have been. Rather than having extensive length requirements for one topic, I would have preferred a variety of topics covered, each with smaller word requirements.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The TA and instructor were always very responsive and extremely helpful.

I didn't really use the TA (Natalie) for a lot during this class, but she was always helpful and available when I had little questions for her. Jim was always available and was excellent at getting responses back immediately!
Excellent TA, who complemented instructor well. Did a great job with the logistics of this class.
Excellent
Natalie had limited office hours so I did not take advantage of them.
T.A. was very useful and available always, Prof. MacBroom was only at Yale a couple days week due to his outside job, but was very available the days he was here.
Both were amazingly helpful and available to answer any questions we might have had. Jim's availability and willingness to take us out into the field was also really great.
Great. I worked a lot with Natalie when I had questions about expectations, and she was always helpful.
At various points in the semester, I contacted both the instructor and TA for assistance. They were both extremely available and provided a very high quality of help.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Provides an introduction into hydrologic concepts.

This course fits into my program as I am focused on water issues, however, the physical aspects of waterways is not something I'm very familiar with, so this class was an excellent introductory class on those topics.

I spent the summer working with a fluvial geomorphologist doing stream restoration in the Pacific Northwest. This class provided a useful background in fundamentals and expanded my knowledge to New England
This course was an elective for me. I thought it would provide a good opportunity to learn about an interesting topic from a real professional in the field.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn more about the functions of rivers.
Elective in my area of interest.
I took this course because it was a little different from what I'd taken in the past and seemed like a good fit to make my courses a little more holistic. I'd also heard wonderful things about it!
I thought that river systems might interest me greatly.
Interest in the material and a need for a more fleshed out background of the basics.
See answer to question 15.
While I was interested in learning about rivers, I took the course primarily to fill my 'bin' requirement.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
Yes and no. The final project was great, but I was expecting to learn more in the rest of the class.
I felt that this course exceeded my expectations and was a really great class to be a part of.
Yes
No, I was hoping for less engineering and more restoration. More ecology would have been nice, too.

Jim is a great teacher and clearly an expert. I liked the class a lot. My one critique is the amount of discussion in the class, and I think the course could be improved by devoting half the class period to discussion of readings and/or restoration projects. Jim hasso much great esperience and has done such interesting work, I think students would like the chance to talk and learn more about all of his projects.

It exceeded them. I had read the reviews from previous years and it looked like the course would be pretty bad, but getting to know Jim was a pleasure and it just took some getting used to to figure out how to handle his teaching style.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: I got out of this course exactly what I expected.
Not completely. I was expecting to learn more concepts and how to apply them to river restoration. I think the course certainly is focused on this, but could be better organized.
Yes and then some
Yes
Yes. I learned a lot. The class project was an especially great learning experience.
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Group work was awesome. Jim does a great job of bringing in applied projects from outside of Yale and pairing groups with those projects to tackle relevant issues.

It was great to learn from other group members and to get to work on a group project, as most work is done in the professional world. However, it was a little frustrating when people did not turn in their work by an agreed upon date.

Advantages were collaborating and bringing different areas of expertise to a project, but as with all group work differences in working styles created some problems but it was overall a great experience.
I recommend limiting your group to 2 or 3--those with 4-5 group members had a much harder time making their schedules work.
Great team work for a practical application.

The group project for this course was the best group project I've done here at FES. The projects had components that could be easily divided, and Jim was extremely helpful in getting us out in the field.
It was great. We could not have done our field measurements solo, and we were efficient in producing our final report.
It was useful to hear other opinions and ideas but difficult to coordinate a group of five.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Try and find a project in an area related to your interests and that could potentially turn into a future capstone project or an internship. However, I recommend choosing a local project, if possible, to gain the hands-on experience of working at a site and taking physical measurements.
Make sure your class project is something you really are interested in and can get a lot out of!
Be ready for the pluses and potential minuses that come with learning from a practitioner instead of an academic.
Tell Jim your interests, because he is eager to tailor the course to what the students want to learn. I appreciated that!
Jim grades very simply, with just checks or check minuses. There is not a lot of feedback on your homework assignments. So don't stress about them too much!
Enjoy the field trips!
